title: Diplomat Told Ukrainians Held-Up Aid Was Tied to Investigations
summary: In revised testimony, envoy is latest impeachment witness to link assistance to Trump's political wishes. WASHINGTON-A diplomat who is a key witness in the House impeachment probe said he told a Ukrainian official this summer that aid to that country would remain frozen until Kyiv committed to investigations sought by President Trump, reversing earlier testimony that he didn't know of any such link.

title: Most Plea Bargains Are Unconstitutional
summary: Harsh punishments for defendants who exercise their right to trial violate the Sixth Amendment.. When is a constitutional right not a right? When you're punished for exercising it. If the government arrests or fines you for something you say, everyone recognizes a violation of the First Amendment, even though you had your say. Yet when prosecutors and courts impose massive punishments on criminal defendants for exercising their Sixth Amendment right to trial by jury, it's considered business as usual-even by the Supreme Court.

title: Elizabeth Warren's Health-Care Hara-Kiri
summary: Democratic voters prefer reforming ObamaCare to trying Medicare for All.. Is the country ready for the "big structural change" that Sen. Elizabeth Warren is promising? Would the Democratic Party be wise to bet that it is? The answers to these questions will shape the outcome of the nomination contest and the general election.

title: Boeing vs. Technological Chaos
summary: Human beings and their machines find it hard to understand each other.. When congressional hearings were inaugurated, they were supposed to be information-seeking exercises. Not much information seeking went on at last week's hearings on the Boeing 737 MAX. Senators gave speeches deploring plane crashes. Even when they asked questions, they seldom waited for answers. And if any legislation results, it will surely be written by staffers based on agendas long ago hashed out.

title: 'Plant-Based Meat' Is All Hat and No Cattle
summary: What happens when consumers realize it's highly processed?. Beyond Meat 's stock has tumbled back to Earth after peaking at $234.90 a share in late July. The "plant-based meat" company's stock closed at $81.45 Tuesday, and it may be the beginning of worse to come. What if the alt-meat industry turns out to be a nothingburger?

title: 'This Could Be Our Future' Review: Building the High Road
summary: Yancey Strickler, co-founder of the online crowdfunding platform Kickstarter, urges us to change the way we view work and society.. Yancey Strickler is one of those tech executives: big thinkers who not only aim to make money but also see themselves as visionaries, ready to remake the world. Yet Mr. Strickler has a better claim to such credentials than most. He is a co-founder and former chief executive of Kickstarter, an online platform for funding creative projects and even small startup businesses through small donations from dozens, hundreds or thousands of individuals. Since its start in 2009, the company has helped pioneer an internet-enabled way of raising money-crowdfunding. Kickstarter claims to have raised more than $4.6 billion from more than 17 million people in its first 10 years, and the crowdfunding model has been adopted by many other niche online platforms.

title: Why Black Democrats Favor Joe Biden
summary: The Obama link is the main attraction, but they also want to keep their health insurance and cars.. Your typical black Democratic primary voter is likely to be middle-aged and female, and right now Joe Biden is her guy. But who's her second choice?

title: Beijing Can't Bring Home the Bacon
summary: Along with slow growth and high-tech oppression, pork shortages may make the Chinese masses squeal.. It might look as though the Communist Party is in complete control of mainland China, but there's a new threat to social stability: African swine fever is devastating the pig population. With pork prices skyrocketing and the virus spreading across the globe, the specter of a crippling pork shortage looms. That has Beijing worried. Pork makes up about 60% of Chinese meat consumption, which accounts for nearly half the world's pork market. Shortages and price spikes, combined with dissatisfaction over slowing economic growth and increasing repression, could produce political unrest. That's the last thing Beijing wants.

title: Notable & Quotable: The Media
summary: 'To beat Trump, both Democrats and the media will need to get it right.'. Jessica Tarlovwriting for the Hill, Nov. 5:

title: Canada Meat Exports to China to Resume
summary: Halt had been triggered by Beijing's concerns over forged export certificates. OTTAWA-Canada said Tuesday that shipments of meat to China would resume following a more than four-month pause sparked by Beijing's concerns over forged export certificates, signaling a possible thaw in a trade-and-diplomatic row fueled by the arrest of a senior Huawei Technologies Co. executive.

title: At China Trade Expo, Xi Touts an Appetite for Imports
summary: Despite a slowing economy China wants to remind the world that it is still a source of global demand. SHANGHAI-Chinese President Xi Jinping on Tuesday inaugurated a trade fair by saying his government will strive for robust domestic growth to benefit global business activity, messages that come as China's economy slows and trade tension with the U.S. persists.

title: California Puts Former Berkshire Insurance Unit Under State Control
summary: California Insurance Co. says it is considering options in response. California regulators seized an insurer formerly owned by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the latest twist in a continuing dispute about whether its sale of the company violated that state's insurance regulations.

title: Retailer Pier 1 Taps Debt Restructuring Expert as Chief Executive
summary: New CEO Robert Riesbeck previously worked at FullBeauty and HHGregg, which both passed through bankruptcy in recent years. Struggling retail chain Pier 1 Imports Inc. has hired a bankruptcy veteran to serve as its new chief executive.

title: Officials See No Disruption to Voting Infrastructure in State Elections
summary: Authorities tout 'unprecedented level of coordination' to ensure election security. Federal and state officials said that elections in several states unfolded without any notable security issues on Tuesday, as they praised improved intelligence sharing, new voting machines and other measures they have taken following foreign attempts to interfere in recent U.S. elections.

title: WW International Shares Fall on Lower Revenue
summary: Company formerly known as Weight Watchers reports a third consecutive quarter of lower revenue. Shares of WW International Inc. fell sharply on Tuesday as the weight-management company reported a third consecutive quarter of lower revenue.

title: Canadian Crude Prices Hit by Keystone Pipeline Shutdown
summary: The closing reduces the ability of producers to move 590,000 barrels a day out of Alberta. The price of Western Canadian Select crude oil is reeling as Canadian oil producers struggle with the continuing shutdown of TC Energy Corp.'s Keystone pipeline.

title: U.S. Officials Offer Ways to Prevent Bicycle Deaths
summary: Analysis suggests better road design, cyclist visibility and helmet usage. Federal safety officials said improved road design, cyclist visibility and helmet usage would curtail the growing number of cyclist deaths, in the National Transportation Safety Board's first detailed look at bike safety in nearly a half-century.

title: Texas Begins Clearing Homeless From Austin Underpasses
summary: State leaders had criticized city policy allowing camping in streets; flyers direct people to already-full shelters. Texas Gov. Greg Abbott is carrying through on his vow to begin clearing the homeless from Austin underpasses this week, as a standoff between city leaders and the state continues.

title: Forever 21 Cuts Number of Store Closures Planned in Bankruptcy
summary: The company cut its planned store closures in half after capturing $100 million in rent savings in negotiations with landlords. Forever 21 Inc. plans to keep more stores open than it expected under its chapter 11 restructuring and has negotiated $100 million in rent savings from landlords, the company's lawyer said in bankruptcy court on Tuesday.

title: Inequality and Those Tax Cuts for the Rich
summary: Clearly, if net payments-taxes paid offset by benefits received-aren't taken into account, then the math that Prof. Blinder cites can only result in an "illegal procedure" penalty. Fifteen yards penalty and ejection from the game.. Picking up on Alan Blinder's football analogy in "Tax Cuts for the Wealthy Make Inequality Worse" (op-ed, Nov. 1), we'll also have to throw a flag and penalize the economists Emmanuel Saez and Gabriel Zucman whom Prof. Blinder cites in his analysis of tax progressivity for not taking into account the very substantial federal benefits paid out to the different income groups. Clearly, if net payments-taxes paid offset by benefits received-aren't taken into account, then the math Prof. Blinder cites can only result in an "illegal procedure" penalty: Fifteen-yard penalty and ejection from the game!

title: China Sells First Euro Bonds Since 2004
summary: Move could encourage Chinese borrowers to cut heavy reliance on dollar funding. China sold bonds in euros for the first time in 15 years, a move that could encourage Chinese companies to follow suit, helping reduce their reliance on dollar funding.

title: Identity Politics, Incivility And National Cohesiveness
summary: Former Georgia Democratic gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams has declared that "identity politics" is the core of the Democratic Party, an ideology which divides, disempowers and separates us, building grievance and resentment. Self-described conservative Peggy Noonan writes: "I am for whatever will hold America together" ("Elijah Cummings and the Little Sisters," Declarations, Oct. 26). That's the spine, heart and soul of what "conservative" means.

title: Companies Should Better Accommodate Grief
summary: We know that health impacts on bereaved parents are severe. Three days of leave hardly seem adequate.. While 89% of employers offer three days of paid bereavement leave, all deaths are not created equal ("Work & Family: The Juggle on the Job When a Loved One Dies," Life & Arts, Oct. 29). Consider, for example, the death of a child-at any age. We know that the health impact on bereaved parents is severe. They are more likely to experience cardiac events, immune dysfunction, depressive symptoms, substance abuse, psychiatric hospitalization and premature mortality. Surviving siblings also are at risk for premature death. Three days of leave hardly seem adequate.

title: Good Riddance to Baghdadi
summary: Who would argue, other than, apparently, Mr. Pantucci, that the world isn't a better place without Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi?. Regarding Raffaello Pantucci's "After Baghdadi, Terrorism Without Ideology" (op-ed, Oct. 31): And your point, Mr. Pantucci, would be? Eliminating a mass murderer who used ideology to justify and encourage psychopathic behavior in his followers may not eradicate such behavior, but as New Yorkers used to say: "It couldn't hoit." Who would argue, other than, apparently, Mr. Pantucci, that the world isn't a better place without Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi?

title: Supreme Court Ponders Rights to Blackbeard Ship-Salvage Images
summary: Supreme Court is hearing a case involving Blackbeard's flagship, but the issue is copyright law rather than rum, parrots or buried treasure. WASHINGTON-Blackbeard's flagship, Queen Anne's Revenge, ran aground near Beaufort, N.C., in 1718, eventually giving rise to a piracy case the Supreme Court heard Tuesday-but the issue is about copyright rather than rum, parrots or buried treasure.

title: Peloton Shares Fall as Company Puts Growth Ahead of Profit
summary: Exercise-equipment and subscription company posts higher-than-expected subscriber growth and revenue. Peloton Interactive Inc. posted a loss but higher-than-expected subscriber and revenue growth in its first quarterly report since its public-market debut.

summary: Service-sector data eases worries that recent slowdown in industrial activity might spread to other sectors. U.S. government-bond yields continued their sharp recent ascent Tuesday following signs of progress in U.S.-China trade talks and strong U.S. service-sector data.

title: Drop in Consumer-Goods Imports Points to Slower U.S. Growth
summary: U.S. posts largest petroleum products surplus on record on import decline. U.S. imports of goods such as cellphones, toys and apparel fell sharply in September, the latest sign that slowing global growth might be spilling into the domestic economy.

summary: Disagreement on union's board about its leader came during Detroit labor talks. The governing board of the United Auto Workers is trying to move past an internal split over the terms of President Gary Jones's recent departure and focus on salvaging the union's reputation amid a corruption probe, contract talks and shrinking membership.

title: 'Very Hungry Caterpillar' Author Eric Carle Sells Company to Penguin Random House
summary: Acquisition is latest bet on children's book market by world's largest publisher. summary: Move follows cases against South Korean companies that supplied fuel to U.S. military bases. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department says it is stepping up efforts to target bid-rigging and other types of collusion that cheat the government in the contracting process.

summary: Investors dumped shares and bonds of the Oklahoma City-based energy company after going-concern warning. summary: Democratic proposal would create new rights for consumers and create a privacy agency. summary: Media measurement firm has been led by an interim chief since spring. Media measurement firm Comscore Inc. has named board Vice Chairman Bill Livek as its new chief executive officer and executive vice chairman as it tries to move past a period of turmoil.

summary: For nearly a century, the LeBaróns have led a tightknit community built on farming wealth in Chihuahua. title: Gert Boyle Stamped Her 'Tough Mother' Image on Columbia Sportswear

She and her college-age son, Tim Boyle, lacked business experience and nearly ran the business into the ground over the next few years.

title: Controlling the Comfort of Your Airplane Seat-From Your Phone
summary: Partnered up with Airbus, an innovative London design firm is fine-tuning app-controlled seats you can adjust on your smartphone. title: Winter's New Eco-Status Symbol: A Recycled Coat
summary: Herno, Italian makers of luxury outerwear, are making puffers with recycled nylon and reused down for sustainability. Inside the brand's environmental tweaks. Outerwear trends this winter lean toward quilted jackets and all-enveloping puffers, both of which are specialties of Italian label Herno. In fact, Herno has been making luxe coats in the town of Lesa since 1948, when husband-and-wife team Giuseppe Marenzi and Alessandra Diana introduced a double-breasted trench, a style that em-bodied the simplicity of postwar fashions.

title: Tyler, The Creator Is a Singular Talent
summary: How hip-hop artist and fashion designer Tyler, The Creator creatively thrives in several different fields-and he's only 28. Tyler, the Creator bursts through the service entrance of Jon & Vinny's, the L.A. restaurant where he asked me to meet him, fixes his eyes on mine and issues a gruff command: "Grab your shit." Without further explanation, he turns on his heels and vanishes the same way he came. I stammer a goodbye to a confused waiter and hurry into the alley out back, where Tyler's behind the wheel of a vintage BMW E30 M3 coupe, its engine growling monstrously. He's wearing black high-water trousers and a white T-shirt decorated with a pixelated flower, both of which he designed for his fashion brand Golf Wang. Our plan was to get a bite, but with Tyler, it turns out, spontaneity rules-"I don't like schedules," he says-and right now he's got matters more urgent than breakfast on the brain. "I need a manicure," he says, showing me his fingernails with a look of repulsion. He yanks the stick shift and rockets down the alley.

Chinese President Xi Jinping offered firm backing for Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam and her attempts to quell the city's antigovernment protests, signaling Beijing's intention to keep the beleaguered chief executive in place despite her record unpopularity among residents.

title: Companies Tie Pay, Performance Ratings to Gender Recruiting Targets
summary: Companies with female finance chiefs are more profitable than those without, a recent study indicates. Pressure from investors and lawmakers to boost gender diversity in the executive ranks and the boardroom are prompting more companies to consider a wider array of C-suite candidates and, increasingly, tie performance reviews and pay to hiring targets.

title: Security Contractor Erik Prince in Talks to Acquire Ukraine's Motor Sich
summary: Trump administration has approached Prince and at least one other potential buyer from the private sector.

title: Indicted Yahoo Hacker's Case Shows Pitfalls of Extradition Efforts
summary: Russian national Alexsey Belan, detained by Greece at U.S. request, was released on bail and, after fleeing to Russia, accused of huge hack. Alexsey Belan was detained, then released-and then the mayhem began.

title: Asia's Huge Trade Pact Is a Paper Tiger in the Making
summary: The withdrawal of India from the broad but shallow agreement reinforces its very limited nature. Asia's Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, billed as a mammoth that could be China's alternative to the Trans-Pacific Partnership, is shaping up to look more like a mouse.

title: Xerox to Sell Stake in Joint Venture to Fujifilm
summary: Companies agree to end 57-year-old joint venture after an attempt at a full merger soured. Xerox Holdings Corp. and Fujifilm Holdings Corp. agreed to end a 57-year-old joint venture more than a year after an attempt at a full merger soured.

title: China's Housing Market Is Finally Cooling. Some Homeowners Are Furious.
summary: Officials have tightened financing to developers and rules on lending for home buyers in an effort to cool the market. TIANJIN, China-Thirty floors above the showroom of a Chinese developer, a 29-year-old woman stood on a small rooftop ledge about 8 feet off the rooftop itself, threatening to jump and declaring that her recent home purchase had ruined her life.

title: Peloton Needs to Keep Pumping
summary: The connected fitness company delivered strong results in first post-IPO report, but it still failed to win over investors. Peloton Interactive has a competition problem. Its rivals, though, aren't today's companies but yesterday's.

title: Dating-Site Owner Match's Results Disappoint
summary: Shares plummet after hours following a weak sales forecast. Shares of Match Group Inc. dropped 16% in after-hours trading Tuesday after the company's financial targets for the current quarter came in below analysts' estimates.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: NYPD Commissioner to Depart; City's Top Detective to Succeed Him
summary: James O'Neill presided over nation's largest police force during a transitional period. New York Police Department Commissioner James O'Neill, who led the nation's largest police force during a period of transition and oversaw an effort to address racial disparities in law enforcement, said he planned to step down from the post.

title: U.S., China Consider Rolling Back Tariffs as Part of Initial Trade Deal
summary: The two countries have agreed in principle to the first of several phases of an agreement to end the trade war. WASHINGTON-U.S. and Chinese officials are actively considering rolling back some tariffs to clinch the partial trade deal under negotiation, according to people familiar with the talks.

title: Giuliani Associate Lev Parnas to Comply With House Subpoena
summary: Parnas and his associate, Igor Fruman, worked closely with Giuliani on Trump's efforts to push for investigations in Ukraine. WASHINGTON-Lev Parnas, an associate of Rudy Giuliani who was arrested last month on campaign-finance charges, in a reversal intends to comply with a congressional subpoena to the extent he can, his lawyer said Monday.

title: WeWork Isn't the Only Stumble for SoftBank's Vision Fund
summary: Other companies the huge tech investment fund has backed have struggled lately. SoftBank Group Corp.'s longtime strategy of dumping mountains of cash on promising young companies to create big winners failed dramatically at WeWork, and is showing cracks at a number of its other investments.

title: Vale CEO Dismissed Warning on Mines Before Deadly Brazil Disaster
summary: Email sent to the miner's top managers prompted the chief executive to pursue the writer's identity and call the writer a 'cancer'. BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil-Vale SA's top managers received an anonymous email warning about the state of the miner's dams two weeks before a deadly disaster, a note that prompted the chief executive to pursue the writer's identity and call the person a "cancer," a police document shows.

title: PG&E Unveils Revised Bankruptcy Insurance Settlement
summary: Insurers can back out of their deal with PG&E if new wildfires push the utility into insolvency. Insurance companies and investors with billions of dollars riding on the outcome of PG&E Corp.'s bankruptcy have reworked provisions of an $11 billion settlement, spelling out the consequences if California's largest utility becomes insolvent.

title: Uber Books Another Quarterly Loss as Revenue Climbs
summary: Ride-hailing company expects profitability on an adjusted basis in 2021. After a string of large quarterly losses, Uber Technologies Inc. is more upbeat about 2021, expecting to turn a profit then even as it faces unrelenting challenges from competitors and regulators across the globe.

title: Fed's Daly Says Three Rate Cuts Appropriate
summary: San Francisco Fed president doesn't see a need to easy monetary policy further. Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said Monday the central bank did the right thing to lower short-term rates three times this year, adding that she doesn't see a need to lower rates further.

title: New York City's Next Top Cop Has Humble Queens Roots
summary: Dermot Shea, son of Irish immigrants, is champion of data-driven crime-fighting. New York City's next police commissioner is a Queens-raised son of Irish immigrants who has worked as a plainclothes narcotics officer and as the New York Police Department's chief of detectives, championing data-driven crime-fighting.

title: White House Officials Fail to Appear for Impeachment Inquiry Testimony
summary: Among the witnesses are a top White House lawyer and an adviser to chief of staff Mick Mulvaney. WASHINGTON-The four administration officials whose testimony impeachment investigators had scheduled for Monday didn't appear for their depositions amid a legal standoff between the White House and Congress over whether they can be compelled to testify.

title: What's Eating Uber?
summary: Food-delivery losses offset improving bottom line of rides business. The good news is that Uber appears to make a profit doing what it was originally meant to do. The bad news is that none of the company's other activities can make that claim.

title: Iran Finds Itself in Crosshairs of Arab Protesters
summary: After expanding its footprint in Middle East, Tehran and its allies draw ire from those angered by poor governance and state violence. The largest mass protests to hit Iraq and Lebanon in decades are posing a direct challenge to the influence Iran has gained in both countries as demonstrators seek to overturn the political order.
